BC-FLIGHT-DELAYS-ART-3TAKES-NYT 
AS AIR TRAFFIC APPROACHES GRIDLOCK, SOLUTIONS PROVING ELUSIVE 

  (EDS: A shorter version of this report, FLIGHT-DELAYS-ABRIDGED,
will also move tonight.) 
(ART ADV: Photos NYT18, 19 are being sent to NYT Photo clients.
Graphics are being sent to NYT graphic clients. Nonsubscribers can
purchase one-time rights by calling 888-603-1036 or
888-346-9867.) By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN   and MATTHEW L. WALD   
 c.2000 N.Y. Times News Service   

   Tuesday ends the second straight summer travel season of chronic
flight delays and cancellations across the United States, and
despite spending billions of dollars and repeated warnings in the
last decade of impending air traffic gridlock, there is no solution
in sight.

   Indeed, most experts now believe that delays, which have risen
nearly 50 percent during the last five years, will become worse,
not better.

   The Federal Aviation Administration, which runs the air traffic
system, predicts that by 2010 the number of airline passengers will
rise 59 percent, to 1 billion. About 70 percent of that increase is
expected to occur at the country's 28 largest airports.

   ``I don't think there is anything on the drawing board right now
that you can say with any credibility is the answer,'' said Kenneth
Mead, the inspector general of the Transportation Department,
parent agency of the FAA.

   ``We wish there was a silver bullet,'' said Jane Garvey, the FAA
administrator, ``but there is not.''

   The story of how the nation's air travel system reached its
current crisis can be traced back to one of the government's most
successful economic initiatives _ airline deregulation _ and to one
of its longest and most expensive bureaucratic blunders: the FAA's
attempts to develop a new air traffic control system.

   It is a tale that involves so many disparate interests shouting
one another down _ from grass-roots organizations to large
corporations to municipalities to labor unions _ that politicians
in Congress and the White House have simply let the system drift
for years.

   A recent review by Mead's office found that the FAA and the
Transportation Department do not even have the tools to determine
the precise causes of most delays.

   And so the airlines blame the FAA, charging that the hours
planes sit idling on runways and the countless appointments missed
by passengers because of an antiquated air traffic control system
cost more than $5 billion last year alone. The FAA counters that
airlines knowingly schedule more takeoffs and landings at major
airports than the system can handle. And both the FAA and airlines
attack Congress for not appropriating enough money to fix the
system, as well as regional authorities for preventing the building
of new runways at congested airports.

   ``It's gotten down to a big finger-pointing contest,'' said
Thomas Brantley, national vice president of the Professional
Airways System Specialists, the union of technicians who maintain
the FAA's air traffic control equipment. ``The reality is,
everybody's got blame to share.''

   There are other factors at work, too.

   Eight years of economic growth has filled airplanes to near
capacity, even as consumers complain about high fares. An unusual
spate of thunderstorms this summer frequently left controllers with
few avenues to reroute air traffic. United Airlines, the world's
largest carrier, canceled more than 20,000 flights during the
summer, largely because of labor disputes, adding to the burden on
passengers and other airlines.

   Critics say that thunderstorms and the growth in passenger
demand are predictable events that the system should handle without
passengers' waiting half a day or more to reach their destinations.
And those passengers are seething.

   ``It's not like we are having typhoons,'' said Sharon Mantel, a
drug company sales representative traveling to Chicago from
LaGuardia Airport one morning in July. ``Shouldn't technology be
able to handle this? It's not like the airplane was invented
yesterday.''

   Indeed, the answer to air traffic control gridlock, whenever it
comes, will involve new technology that lets controllers track more
planes in the sky _ and, possibly, economics that let market forces
allocate the system's scarce resources.

   Any changes, however, must guarantee the same level of safety.

   TRAFFIC CONTROL IN TRANSFORMATION

   A generation ago, life was much simpler for airlines and air
traffic controllers. Government regulators told the airlines when
and where they could fly, and how much they could charge.
Bureaucrats made sure every city was served and that popular cities
had no more service than they could handle.

   The drawback was that flying was expensive.

   Deregulation of the industry in 1978 transformed air travel into
mass transportation. It also hit the industry like an earthquake.
Venerable carriers disappeared; low-fare upstarts came and went.
The survivors established so-called hubs at major airports,
increasing their efficiency by flying passengers in, transferring
them to other planes, and flying them on to their final
destinations.

   Today, the airline industry carries three times as many
passengers as it did in 1978 at average fares that are 40 percent
lower, adjusting for inflation.

   But while the industry was transformed, the air traffic control
system has remained virtually unchanged. At its heart are a
collection of ground-based navigation beacons and radar stations
that divide the 3.5 million square miles of airspace over the
continental United States into lanes, literal highways, along which
most airplanes are dispatched single file, like railroad cars.

   Because radar _ developed for the military in World War II _ is
arguably better at spotting attack planes than tracking friendly
jets, the FAA has long stipulated that planes be separated by at
least five miles horizontally and 1,000 feet vertically. That clogs
the routes taken by the 20,000 scheduled flights each day.

   ``A bunch of guys with slide rules, pocket protectors and tape
on their glasses figured this out a long time ago,'' said William
Blackmer, the top safety and technology expert at the National Air
Traffic Controllers Association, the union for 15,000 FAA
controllers.

   When a storm hits, controllers begin closing off individual
highways and spacing planes farther apart, regardless of original
scheduling, contributing to delays on the ground.

   Even when the weather is perfect, departures are not spread
evenly throughout the day: For a hub to be successful, planes must
arrive and depart in waves. Airlines also try to provide frequent
service from their hubs for the convenience of business travelers,
who pay the highest fares.

   The irony is that inviting everybody to travel when they prefer
means fewer planes arrive or depart on time.

   nn

   Mead, the Transportation Department's inspector general, found
that airlines frequently schedule flights beyond an airport's
capacity even in perfect weather, let alone factoring in bad
weather, when departure and arrival rates can be cut in half.

   For example, at New Jersey's Newark International Airport one
day earlier this year, Mead said he found that during one four-hour
period, airlines had scheduled more planes to take off than could
be managed by the tower. Last year, Newark had the second highest
number of delays recorded by the FAA, after O'Hare International
Airport at Chicago.

   Continental Airlines, which uses Newark as a hub, said it had
spread out arrivals and departures to stay below the airport's
capacity throughout the day. It also has replaced smaller airplanes
with larger ones, to keep takeoffs and landings flat while
accommodating more passengers.

   ``If we scheduled fewer flights, then people couldn't travel,''
said Greg Brenneman, Continental's president. ``It is not incumbent
on the airlines to be the least common denominator here. It is
incumbent on the government to have a system that allows people to
travel when they want to travel.''

   Several government commissions have urged expanded use of
secondary airports to ease the strain on the system. Southwest
Airlines, the country's seventh-largest carrier, has had enormous
success bypassing major airports, providing frequent service
between cities like Baltimore and Providence or Dallas and Houston.
That has helped Southwest achieve the best on-time performance of
any major carrier. But the other airlines continue to favor the hub
system.

   The airlines would like to see busy airports enlarged. That is
what both United and American Airlines executives have said they
would prefer at O'Hare, for instance, where they operate hubs. But
residents near O'Hare have opposed any expansion.

   Rep. Henry Hyde Jr., the region's Republican congressman, has
joined with Rep. Jesse Jackson Jr., a Democrat from Chicago, to
back construction of a new airport south of the city _ but the
airlines have said they would not fly there.

   Most other major airports also have difficulty expanding, either
because there is no space, as is the case at Newark and New York's
LaGuardia Airport, or because of opposition by area residents. From
1995 through 1999, only three new runways were put into service at
the 28 biggest airports, according to the Transportation
Department.

   The introduction of 50- and 70-seat jets has also increased air
traffic congestion. These jets are rapidly replacing
propeller-driven planes on many commuter routes and are often
preferred by passengers. But unlike prop-driven planes, which fly
at lower altitudes and can take off and land on shorter runways,
these jets require similar facilities as their bigger cousins,
adding to the competition for space on the ground and in the air.

   In 1995, there were just 35 of these smaller jets in the
nation's fleet. Last year, there were 407. The Transportation
Department estimates the number will grow 25 percent annually,
becoming 19 percent of the total domestic fleet by 2011.

   FROM BRAINSTORM TO BOONDOOGLE

   The growth in air traffic was supposed to be easily managed by a
sophisticated control system that the FAA began developing in 1981.
In the wake of that year's air traffic controller's strike, when
11,000 controllers were fired by President Reagan, the FAA began
looking for a system that could manage more traffic with fewer
controllers.

   What came to be known as the Advanced Automation System, was the
centerpiece of a 10-year, $12 billion plan to modernize air traffic
control. Though the overall system of radar and navigation beacons
was unchanged, the plan promised to save billions of dollars by
enabling controllers to ``work smarter, not harder,'' the FAA
administrator at the time said.

   It turned out to be a gigantic white elephant. In 1994, after
its cost had tripled, the system's capabilities were shown to be
much less than promised and it was still 10 years from completion,
the FAA decided to scale back the project. The cost, according to
the General Accounting Office, amounted to $2.8 billion.

   The failure was just another example of the FAA's storied
incompetence in procurement: For years, the agency has been rebuked
by members of Congress and outside critics.

   ``The Federal Aviation Administration currently lacks the
organizational, management, and financial wherewithal to keep pace
with the dynamic aviation community,'' the National Civil Aviation
Review Commission, a panel set up by Congress, concluded in 1996.
The Commission also warned at the time that ``rapidly growing
demand combined with a reduction in capacity, as the result of
continued reliance on outdated equipment, will bring our nation's
aviation system to gridlock soon after the turn of the century.''

   A NEW STRATEGY

   The FAA has shown some improvement in the last five years. For
one thing, Congress mandated a five-year term for the
administrator, slowing the turnover at the top.

   After the debacle with the Advanced Automation System, the FAA
adopted a more modest approach to modernizing air traffic control _
a strategy Garvey, the administrator since 1997, sums up as ``build
a little; test a little; deploy a little.''

   The FAA replaced its old mainframe computers with newer models
and installed color radar displays. System crashes, which in the
1990s frequently forced controllers to track jets on slips of
paper, are now rare.

   But many problems remain.

   The original $12 billion modernization program that was supposed
to be completed in 1991 now has a budget of $40 billion through
2004 with no completion date scheduled.

   The new mainframe computers that form the heart of the air
traffic system are IBM models built in the 1990s that have already
gone out of production. The FAA could not buy IBM's newest machines
because they would not run JOVIAL, the 1960s-era programming
language used in the system's software.

   JOVIAL, which stands for Jules Own Version of the International
Algebraic Language, was created by programmer Jules Schwartz 40
years ago as part of a contract for the Strategic Air Command. The
FAA plans to switch to a more modern computer language, but the
transition ``is very complex and it is going to take literally
years,'' said William Shumann, an agency spokesman.

   The FAA also had high hopes for a plan called the Wide Area
Augmentation System, intended to use the constellation of military
satellites that make up the Global Positioning System to enable
planes to fly virtually independent of controllers on the ground.

   It was supposed to be operating by 1998, but also proved much
more complicated _ and expensive _ than the FAA first thought.

   The system was made available on a limited basis last week, but
is not scheduled to be completed until 2002. Few believe it will
make a significant contribution toward reducing delays.

   ``The FAA parades these acquisitions before Congress like they
know what they are getting, but they haven't figured out yet what
they need,'' said Mead.

   Meanwhile, a group of air freight carriers, frustrated by the
FAA's failures, is developing its own air traffic system using
satellites. Under this system, each airplane broadcasts its
location and identity to all other airplanes. Every cockpit has a
display screen, a miniature version of those in air traffic control
centers, that tells pilots the flight paths and altitudes of other
airplanes in the vicinity.

   Because pilots and controllers have more precise information
than is provided by the current radar-based system, airplanes can
fly closer together, as well as land and take off more closely.

   Now, pilots must wait for clearance from the tower before they
take off. But with the satellite system, if the crew saw that it
had the necessary three-mile separation from the previous take off,
they could decide on their own to depart.

   The new system has been tested in the Midwest. Executives with
United Parcel Service, which is leading the news system's
development, said they believe it can be useful at the UPS hub in
Louisville, Ky. But the FAA, which has been working with the cargo
carriers, has some reservations.

   ``What if the second pilot leaves before he has the three
miles?'' asked David Ford, the FAA official in charge of developing
such systems. ``Who gets credited with the operational error?''

   For now, the FAA is working on deploying a series of discrete
systems designed to improve the efficiency of takeoffs and landings
at busy airports and to allow some airplanes to fly more direct
routes. But these improvements will not come close to addressing
the long-term growth in air traffic.

   ``We know we can make some changes,'' said Steven Brown, the
FAA's acting associate administrator for air traffic services.
``Those will be marginal _ not unimportant, but marginal.''

   nn

   REVOLUTIONIZING THE AIR TRAFFIC SYSTEM

   Such talk fuels critics who say that the only way to end the
impending gridlock in the skies is to junk the FAA _ or junk the
economics on which its management of the air traffic system is
based.

   Federal air traffic control services are paid for by taxes on
airline tickets, cargo and fuel. Users like commercial airlines do
not pay any more to use the system than private pilots; small
planes get the same priority as jumbo jets.

   ``The problem is that the resources are not priced properly,''
said Richard Golaszewski, a consultant who has advised the FAA and
several European countries. ``In fact, they are not priced at
all.'' That means that airlines have no incentive to limit their
use of air traffic control services even at the most crowded
airports.

   For years, economists have urged the government to switch to a
fee-based system that would force users to pay for the services
they use. Raising prices at peak hours would put pressure on
airlines to reduce congestion. They might also switch service to
underutilized secondary airports, or replace some smaller jets with
less frequent service on bigger planes.

   ``This is the unfinished business of deregulation,'' Golaszewski
said. ``We have taken off all of the controls on what airlines can
do, but we haven't done anything to balance demand and capacity.''

   Many advocates go farther and say that the air traffic control
system needs to be separated from the FAA and handed over to a new,
independent entity that would operate like a business.

   A plan that the Clinton administration sent to Capitol Hill in
1994 as part of Vice President Al Gore's campaign to reinvent
government never got out of committee, even though the House was
still controlled by Democrats at the time.

   Various privatization proposals have been floated in Congress
during the years, but none have made any progress.

   ``I told him I'll do all I can to kill this idea,'' Rep. James
Oberstar, a Democrat from Minnesota who was then head of the House
Transportation Committee's aviation subcommittee, recalled in a
recent interview, referring to Gore.

   Oberstar, now the ranking minority member on the committee, said
that privatizing the FAA would not break the aviation gridlock.
``Who is to say that the private sector is going to do a better job
than the public sector?'' he said. ``The same private sector that
brings you delays?''

   But the FAA, he added, is already beginning to act more like a
business. Congress passed legislation a few years ago creating a
15-member advisory council to supervise the agency. A bill passed
this spring directed the council to hire a chief operating officer
to run the air traffic control system.

   Congress also increased the FAA's budget by $10 billion during
the next three years to $40 billion. And it required that funds
collected from ticket taxes be spent only on aviation-related
projects, such as expanding airports, rather than being used to
finance other government programs.

   ``What we want to do is to give these things a chance and see if
they won't make a difference,'' said Phil Boyer, president of the
Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association, a longtime opponent of air
control system privatization whose 360,000 members make up more
than half the licensed private pilots in the country.

   But critics say that the FAA has been given too many chances
already. Mead, the inspector general, said that Congress has been
asking the FAA since 1993 to assign a cost to each of the services
its provides, as a prerequisite to charging user fees. Congress
finally ordered that study in 1996; the FAA now says it will be
completed at the end of 2002.

   Given the recent public outcry about flight delays, interest in
privatization is on the rise again. Six years ago, when the Clinton
administration floated its proposal, the concept was relatively
new. Today, several countries, including Germany, Canada and New
Zealand, have successfully contracted air traffic services to
private companies.

   Nav Canada, the only private company in the world to run a
national air traffic control system, has proven the most intriguing
to policy makers in Washington. Before the nonprofit corporation
was set up in 1996, the Canadian air traffic control system
suffered many of the same problems that plague the FAA: Its
equipment was antiquated, and a proposed replacement was behind
schedule and far over budget.

   Since then, Nav Canada has managed to reduce air traffic delays,
cut costs and revamp its technology. A cost-accounting system
enables the company to charge users by the flight. Managers who
worked under both systems say the new arrangement has enhanced
safety, precisely because regulation and operations have been
assigned to two different organizations. Airlines in the United
States would like to be able to pay Nav Canada to control some
domestic flights, but for now there is no mechanism for Nav Canada
to accept such payments.

   Some staff members on Capitol Hill have drafted a privatization
proposal modeled on Nav Canada and are looking for a senator to
sponsor it. Many analysts say the alternatives _ inching along with
current plans or returning to tighter government regulation of air
travel _ are unthinkable.

   ``My guess is that if we have one more summer as bad as this
one, or even one worse than this one, finally it will force the
issue,'' said John Meyer, a retired economics professor at Harvard
who is in favor of introducing user fees.

satellites that make up the Global Positioning System to enable
planes to fly virtually independent of controllers on the ground.

   It was supposed to be operating by 1998, but also proved much
more complicated _ and expensive _ than the FAA first thought.

   The system was made available on a limited basis last week, but
is not scheduled to be completed until 2002. Few believe it will
make a significant contribution toward reducing delays.

   ``The FAA parades these acquisitions before Congress like they
know what they are getting, but they haven't figured out yet what
they need,'' said Mead.

   Meanwhile, a group of air freight carriers, frustrated by the
FAA's failures, is developing its own air traffic system using
satellites. Under this system, each airplane broadcasts its
location and identity to all other airplanes. Every cockpit has a
display screen, a miniature version of those in air traffic control
centers, that tells pilots the flight paths and altitudes of other
airplanes in the vicinity.

   Because pilots and controllers have more precise information
than is provided by the current radar-based system, airplanes can
fly closer together, as well as land and take off more closely.

   Now, pilots must wait for clearance from the tower before they
take off. But with the satellite system, if the crew saw that it
had the necessary three-mile separation from the previous take off,
they could decide on their own to depart.

   The new system has been tested in the Midwest. Executives with
United Parcel Service, which is leading the news system's
development, said they believe it can be useful at the UPS hub in
Louisville, Ky. But the FAA, which has been working with the cargo
carriers, has some reservations.

   ``What if the second pilot leaves before he has the three
miles?'' asked David Ford, the FAA official in charge of developing
such systems. ``Who gets credited with the operational error?''

   For now, the FAA is working on deploying a series of discrete
systems designed to improve the efficiency of takeoffs and landings
at busy airports and to allow some airplanes to fly more direct
routes. But these improvements will not come close to addressing
the long-term growth in air traffic.

   ``We know we can make some changes,'' said Steven Brown, the
FAA's acting associate administrator for air traffic services.
``Those will be marginal _ not unimportant, but marginal.''

   REVOLUTIONIZING THE AIR TRAFFIC SYSTEM

   Such talk fuels critics who say that the only way to end the
impending gridlock in the skies is to junk the FAA _ or junk the
economics on which its management of the air traffic system is
based.

   Federal air traffic control services are paid for by taxes on
airline tickets, cargo and fuel. Users like commercial airlines do
not pay any more to use the system than private pilots; small
planes get the same priority as jumbo jets.

   ``The problem is that the resources are not priced properly,''
said Richard Golaszewski, a consultant who has advised the FAA and
several European countries. ``In fact, they are not priced at
all.'' That means that airlines have no incentive to limit their
use of air traffic control services even at the most crowded
airports.

   For years, economists have urged the government to switch to a
fee-based system that would force users to pay for the services
they use. Raising prices at peak hours would put pressure on
airlines to reduce congestion. They might also switch service to
underutilized secondary airports, or replace some smaller jets with
less frequent service on bigger planes.

   ``This is the unfinished business of deregulation,'' Golaszewski
said. ``We have taken off all of the controls on what airlines can
do, but we haven't done anything to balance demand and capacity.''

   Many advocates go farther and say that the air traffic control
system needs to be separated from the FAA and handed over to a new,
independent entity that would operate like a business.

   A plan that the Clinton administration sent to Capitol Hill in
1994 as part of Vice President Al Gore's campaign to reinvent
government never got out of committee, even though the House was
still controlled by Democrats at the time.

   Various privatization proposals have been floated in Congress
during the years, but none have made any progress.

   ``I told him I'll do all I can to kill this idea,'' Rep. James
Oberstar, a Democrat from Minnesota who was then head of the House
Transportation Committee's aviation subcommittee, recalled in a
recent interview, referring to Gore.

   Oberstar, now the ranking minority member on the committee, said
that privatizing the FAA would not break the aviation gridlock.
``Who is to say that the private sector is going to do a better job
than the public sector?'' he said. ``The same private sector that
brings you delays?''

   But the FAA, he added, is already beginning to act more like a
business. Congress passed legislation a few years ago creating a
15-member advisory council to supervise the agency. A bill passed
this spring directed the council to hire a chief operating officer
to run the air traffic control system.

   Congress also increased the FAA's budget by $10 billion during
the next three years to $40 billion. And it required that funds
collected from ticket taxes be spent only on aviation-related
projects, such as expanding airports, rather than being used to
finance other government programs.

   ``What we want to do is to give these things a chance and see if
they won't make a difference,'' said Phil Boyer, president of the
Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association, a longtime opponent of air
control system privatization whose 360,000 members make up more
than half the licensed private pilots in the country.

   But critics say that the FAA has been given too many chances
already. Mead, the inspector general, said that Congress has been
asking the FAA since 1993 to assign a cost to each of the services
its provides, as a prerequisite to charging user fees. Congress
finally ordered that study in 1996; the FAA now says it will be
completed at the end of 2002.

   Given the recent public outcry about flight delays, interest in
privatization is on the rise again. Six years ago, when the Clinton
administration floated its proposal, the concept was relatively
new. Today, several countries, including Germany, Canada and New
Zealand, have successfully contracted air traffic services to
private companies.

   Nav Canada, the only private company in the world to run a
national air traffic control system, has proven the most intriguing
to policy makers in Washington. Before the nonprofit corporation
was set up in 1996, the Canadian air traffic control system
suffered many of the same problems that plague the FAA: Its
equipment was antiquated, and a proposed replacement was behind
schedule and far over budget.

   Since then, Nav Canada has managed to reduce air traffic delays,
cut costs and revamp its technology. A cost-accounting system
enables the company to charge users by the flight. Managers who
worked under both systems say the new arrangement has enhanced
safety, precisely because regulation and operations have been
assigned to two different organizations. Airlines in the United
States would like to be able to pay Nav Canada to control some
domestic flights, but for now there is no mechanism for Nav Canada
to accept such payments.

   Some staff members on Capitol Hill have drafted a privatization
proposal modeled on Nav Canada and are looking for a senator to
sponsor it. Many analysts say the alternatives _ inching along with
current plans or returning to tighter government regulation of air
travel _ are unthinkable.

   ``My guess is that if we have one more summer as bad as this
one, or even one worse than this one, finally it will force the
issue,'' said John Meyer, a retired economics professor at Harvard
who is in favor of introducing user fees.
